[quote="ebayfan414":2pg6r25w]Hi....I had a question for everyone. I recently downloaded the trial version and began to create a game. However, I have paused it's creation because I think it might be a bit controversial, and I don't want to waste my time for nothing. The game is about an angel that gets horny and wants to experience sex, so he is sent to earth. You are the angel, (Which, by the way, you can choose to be a straight or gay male, or straight or gay female) and your mission is to have sex with four people. As you can see, it's an adult game. So I want to know people's response to this idea; If I finish the game and post it, will people bombard me with outraged e-mails, or is this more of an open-minded crowd which will try the game? Please let me know, as I don't want to spend time creating a game that no one will play. Thanks[/quote:2pg6r25w]

Posts.EditableText: Personally, I think there should be some type of limit or rating on the material within a game. Sure, the game(s) that are for adults have the warning but there as simple to access as non-adult games. The ones available in the archive aren't quite that playable but still... let's assume otherwise. I've played around with the idea before just to see if I could make one but I'd probably never post it on here for the reason I stated above. Gotta watch out for the impressionable minds...

Posts.EditableText:
Not that I play Hentai, but most hentai games involve your character sleeping with atleast a cousin.

I also know that in hardcore roleplaying muds characters, conflicts, and emotes can get quite graphic. I've heard of a mud I believe was called Armageddon or something similar. Takes place in some dark post-apocalyptic type setting, characters regularly are murderous cretins out for there own ends and such. It's not uncommon for female characters to be raped or killed, if only because in that roleplayed scenario men are dominant in a Mad Max type world. I'm sure I've managed to make a game with a million redeemable qualities seem awful, so I suggest you research the game yourself before forming opinions. I merely wanted to add to the defense that many interactive-fiction players, and similarly mud players, prefer a more mature atmosphere and gamestyle.

Posts.EditableText: Actually, I didn't dump the options because of anyone. I just decided that it wasn't worth it. (Too time consuming.) Anyway, I actually posted a short demo, because I didn't see the notice that said "No Demos" until after. It didn't get posted anyway. (As the notice said it wouldn't.) But I saw that it said that the game would be checked to see if it was full length, and appropriate. I e-mailed Alex to find out what that meant, but I didn't get any response. Maybe I sent it to the wrong address. What I want to know is, what does "check for appropriate" mean? Does it mean appropriate, as in without bugs and things, or appropriate as in not "adult," as mine is. Because I saw that there are adult games posted, unless that was before a new "No adult games" rule. Anyway, please let me know, because I don't want to continue programming an unuseable game. (Which is taking me quite a while-I'm not even halfway done yet.) Thanks---Ebayfan414
